Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: An Integrated Approach to Performance Modeling and Optimization of Big-data Scientific Workflows

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Next-generation e-science is producing colossal amounts of data, commonly known as Big Data, on the order of terabyte at present and petabyte or even exabyte in the predictable future. These scientific applications typically feature data- and network-intensive workflows comprised of computing modules with intricate inter-module dependencies. Application users oftentimes need to manually configure their computing workflows in distributed environments in an ad-hoc manner, which significantly limits the productivity of scientists and constrains the utilization of resources.

The end-to-end performance of big data scientific workflows depends on both the mapping scheme that determines module assignment and the scheduling policy that determines resource allocation. These two aspects of a workflow-based research process are traditionally treated as two separate topics, and the interactions between them have not been fully explored. As the scale and complexity of scientific workflows and network environments rapidly increase, each individual aspect of performance optimization has limited success. This research is an in-depth investigation into workflow execution dynamics in resource sharing environments to explore the interactions between workflow mapping and node scheduling on a unified application-support platform. The idea is to build a three-layer workflow optimization architecture that seamlessly integrates three interrelated components based on rigorous algorithmic design, theoretical dynamics analysis, and real network implementation, deployment, and evaluation. The successful completion of this project will provide a solid mathematical foundation for the analysis and control of system dynamics of big data scientific workflows, produce a suite of cooperative mapping and scheduling optimization solutions to facilitate scientific collaborations, and add an additional level of intelligence to existing workflow engines widely adopted in the current grid and cloud computing middleware. The resulting workflow optimization solutions will benefit a broad spectrum of workflow-based scientific applications

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project is to analyze and optimize the performance of large-scale scientific workflows in complex network environments by conducting an in-depth investigation into workflow execution dynamics and exploring the interactions between workflow mapping and node scheduling. Towards this goal, we built a three-layer workflow architecture that seamlessly integrates three interrelated components, i.e. resource abstraction, module mapping, and node scheduling, based on rigorous algorithmic design, theoretical dynamics analysis, and real network implementation, deployment, and evaluation.

The workflow scheduling/mapping algorithms we proposed are able to minimize the makespan, maximize the throughput, and significantly reduce dynamic energy consumption of big data scientific workflows, while meeting various performance requirements, such as cost and reliability. During the entire award period, this project has involved the participation of three Ph.D. students and four master students, two of whom are female students.

We investigated the workflow optimization problems in cloud environments and refined the cost models and mapping/scheduling algorithms to account for practical cloud-specific constraints/objectives. A Ph.D. student supported by this grant went to the ACM Mid-Southeast Chapter Conference on Nov. 11, 2016, and won the 2nd place in the graduate program by presenting our work "Science Workflows in the Gaussian Cloud".

We parallelized the existing and new workflow mapping and scheduling algorithms for a quick calculation of mapping/scheduling solutions, which could be further used in a faster dynamic reconfiguration, either locally or globally. A master student graduated in summer 2017 with a thesis based on this research, titled "Enhanced Throughput for Workflow Scheduling using Parallelism Computation and Informed Search".

We formulated the workflow mapping problems in faulty network environments to analyze and achieve workflow reliability by incorporating fault-tolerance constraints in the mapping algorithms. A resulted paper titled "Scheduling for Energy Efficiency and Throughput Maximization in a Faulty Cloud Environment" was published in the proceedings of the 23rd IEEE International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems (ICPADS 2017), Shenzhen, China, Dec. 15-17, 2017.

Three student poster presentations directly resulted from this project research were presented at the ACM Richard Tapia Celebration of Diversity in Computing (Tapia 2018), Orlando, FL, Sep. 19-22, 2018.

A paper titled "Energy-Aware Workflow Scheduling and Optimization in Clouds using Bat Algorithm", based on the research conducted in and results obtained from this project, was presented at the 13th Workshop on Workflows in Support of Large-Scale Science (WORKS 2018), in conjunction with the International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis (SC 2018).

We implemented and deployed a real network testbed using Chameleon system (a configurable experimental environment for large-scale cloud research). Different workflow mapping/scheduling algorithms proposed in this project for various workflow optimization problems have been implemented and tested in this real network environment, and compared with other existing ones in the literature to show the performance superiority of our solutions. A master thesis and graduation directly under this research would be expected in spring 2019.

In this project, we also tackled the problem of multi-objective optimization for large-scale workflow scheduling in cloud environments, and proposed a genetic algorithm (GA) based solution to optimize execution time, energy consumption and cost. This research was selected to present in the ACM Mid-Southeast Chapter Conference on Nov. 15-16, 2018.
